title: Swift is a safe programming language
att1: The "if" statements requires brace brackets to open and close the statement.
att2: The switch statements need to have a default statement.

title: Swift offers type inference
att1: Developers don't need to spend time on annotating variables with type information in most cases. The Swift compiler can determine the type from the value that a variable is getting set with.

title: Swift Generics
att1: Swift introduces Generics. Generics are functions that can be reused with different variable type without rewriting the each type.

title: Swift Tuples provide compound variables
att1: A Tuple makes it possible to group multiple elements into a single compound variable. A Tuple can be of any permutation types like (Int, Int) or (int, String) or (String, Bool) or something else.

title: Swift String types
att1: It is very easy to concatenate strings with Swift, using "+=" and compare strings with just "==".

title: Swift Dictionaries
att1: It is similar to JavaScript using square brackets. It is also called hash tables.

title: Swift adds optional semicolons
att1: Yes, similar to JavaScript, adding semicolon to end of a programming statement is not required and it is optional.

title: Swift Closures
att1: Swift comes with closures and ability to pass functions as first class objects. The good news, yes, it is similar to JavaScript.

title: Swift Protocols
att1: Swift protocols are similar to Java interfaces. The protocols are used for sketching out a blueprint for a collection of classes.

title: Swift Automatic reference counting
att1: The Automatic reference counting which it is similar to iOS Objective-C solutions.

title: Swift Signed and unsigned integers
att1: Swift is offering signed and unsigned integers for one, two, four and eight bytes. This is similar to iOS Objective-C language.
